content.question: Dr. Seymour wants to test her theory about the universality of emotional expressions. She shows her students various people’s faces and asks them to identify which of six emotional expressions is displayed. She records the accuracy of her students’ results in the graph. What of the following describes a theoretical perspective that best explains why there is a higher rate of accuracy for recognition of the emotional expressions of fear and anger?

choices.label: The expressions for disgust, sadness, and happiness are similar, potentially leading to confusion among students.
The same facial muscles are used for all emotional expressions, so it was difficult for students to detect which emotional expression was displayed.
Because recognition of fear and anger may be related to survival mechanisms, we are more easily able to detect those emotional expressions.
The students are unfamiliar with the facial expressions associated with these various emotions, leaving them unable to recognize them with accuracy.

content.answer: Because recognition of fear and anger may be related to survival mechanisms, we are more easily able to detect those emotional expressions.
